title: 115_hr1728
content: BOUNDARY MODIFICATION, MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDS OF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA, IDAHO. The curr_chunk provides definitions for key terms related to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, including Conservation Area, Gateway West, Map, Sage-grouse species, and Secretary. It also outlines the modification of the Conservation Area boundary to include certain areas. The boundary of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of BLM Administered Lands and 86 acres of BOR Administered Lands, while excluding approximately 761 acres of Segment 8 Revised Proposed Route. The Gateway West Transmission Line project excludes approximately 761 acres of land for Segment 8 and 1,845 acres for Segment 9. The Secretary must issue a right-of-way to Gateway West within 90 days of the enactment of this section. The Secretary must issue a right-of-way to Gateway West within 90 days for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines, aligning with proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. Conditions for the right-of-way must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. During construction, Gateway West must mitigate impacts of transmission lines according to the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework, with costs capped at $8,543,440. Additionally, they must contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area for segments 8 and 9 to the Bureau of Land Management Foundation. The revised proposed route for Segment 9 of Gateway West will encompass 1,845 acres and will be used for conservation purposes, including enhancing National Landscape Conservation System Units in Idaho. Gateway West will cover all costs associated with boundary modifications, surveys, recording costs, and other reasonable expenses. The Secretary will administer the lands as part of the Conservation Area in accordance with Public Law 103-64 and the National Landscape Conservation System. The Secretary will administer lands in the Conservation Area in accordance with Public Law 103-64 and the National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A map will be available for public inspection, and a management plan amendment will address long-term management of the lands. The Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area to address long-term management of specific lands, including determining appropriate activities, continuing livestock grazing, allowing motorized access on existing roads, and permitting hunting and fishing in accordance with laws and regulations. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation is also addressed in the document. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, expanded scientific understanding, voluntary conservation activities, and identification of cultural treasures on public lands.
